reviewText: Bridge Constructor is a game that highlights the dangers of government privatization. It allows me to play as a slovenly, morally-void government contractor building really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ bridges for vehicles for a nation-state consisting of several islands. They have really low standards as to what a bridge is supposed to do, just as long as a minimum of total vehicles get across. Did the bridge collapse after those two cars got across? That's fine, they've already cleared the check and the remaining budget goes right into your slush fund. Smarter contractors than I will take advantage of the game's really weird physics engine to launch cars onto the exit point, therefore saving time, money, and more money. The government finds this acceptable, presumably because they like a good show and will think you are some kind of bridge circus man or wizard. So if you feel like screwing the taxpayer, why not give this game a go?

reviewText: This game is awesome. It’s a simple premise: You build bridges. In reality it is a puzzle game with many solutions. Each level has a set of materials and a budget to work within, but it is up to you how you want to end up bridging the gap. That’s not to say most of your “solutions” won’t fail miserably. You are also constrained by physics and the properties of the given materials. In addition, it is not enough that your structure simply doesn’t collapse under its own weight; it has to be able to support traffic of different loads. I’ve lost count of the number of times that some trucks barely made it to the other side as my bridge built with spit and good intentions fell into a shattered ruin in their wake. This makes even the failures entertaining as you look what when wrong and iteratively adjust your design until it works. I definitely recommend it to the engineering-minded as it will occasionally force you to think outside the box to solve the problem at hand.

How come this game has been greenlit? I have played many bridge constructor games on Flash, standalone or mobile apps; not all of them were good but most featured better physics and playability/UI than this one.
The physics really sucks: it's slow like it was slow-motion, moreover it's impossible to speed it up! So one waits for way too long for the trucks to cross a bridge. Even my girlfriend who knows only about Flash and casual games, looking at the game and watching the trucks fall off a breaking bridge, said it looks amateurish.

Note to dev: scaling down the objects & world so that the physics simulation would run more realistically on Unity (which the game seems to be made off) is really no big deal!

Some GUI textures are even 'optimized' with a 256-colors palette, like if our computers lack bytes of VRAM...

Everything from the game system to the GUI feels mobile (which is an excellent thing... on small touchscreens), nothing seems to have been redesigned for computers... except the steep price!

I played up to the middle of the second world; I wanted to give this game a chance. But it's frustrating and repetitive, and the appealing settings/bridges shown in the promotional screenshots had yet to come into play.

This is definitely a bad game, boring and disrespectful to the players who are just treated as customers (what's this omnipresent 'Share on Facebook' on a single player premium computer game?!)
Avoid at all cost.

Bridge Constructor is a brilliant game that puts you in the position of a builder constructing bridges across the 5 islands within the game. Each level tests your skills at being able to solve how to build a bridge in a means to get vehicles across. Anybody who knows of a program called West Point Bridge Designer will find this game to be quite similar, but the achievements and challenges presented will hook you right in. While you are able to build a sensible, well-thought bridge that will do the job perfectly, it's extremely fun to be able to build crazy bridges with massive jumps that still transport vehicles. The physics engine is so fun to play around with through each bridge design - launching cars off your ramps" in the hopes of reaching the end - and the ability to do what you will when constructing bridges to finish each level is amazing.\n\nA game that I strongly recommend to anybody interested in purchasing this game."

This is a very entertaining game, even more so if you can convince a couple of friends to join in the fun and share their own wonderfully unbelievable screenshots and videos. Once you accept that the physics are mostly imaginary, a lot of the bridges become a lot more fun to figure out (especially when you're trying to get a nice explosion set up for the Perfect Screenshot). The second set of islands with slopes, that gives you access to tank trucks a lot faster, really strives to make you be creative both with your bridges and your explosions and was really enjoyable after making somewhat reasonable bridges on the first islands got a bit dull. I didn't expect to stick to this game for so many hours, the first few bridges definitely are addictive!

There is something really exciting about this game.

If you like to build up and test right away and change again, then be proud of yourself when it works, you should try it.

It is really fun, interesting, and give you at least 20 hours of construction.

reviewText:
This game doesn't revolutionize anything, it's the standard bridge builder. But it's a nice game! I've seen some other reviews talking about bugged physics but I just finished every level and nothing weird ever happened.

The definitely-made-for-mobile interface can be a turn off for some people, but it does its job very well, it's not a poor port. The fact that using the right mouse click is very useful goes to prove that, in my opinion.

Some levels have a 'crazy bridge' sign, meaning you'll need to build some outrageous bridge to beat that level. These are very fun, of course, but the construction method start to feel weak in these levels. Feels like you should have more control over the building, like defining exactly what would be solid and what wouldn't etc (these things are automatically defined depending on the angle and adjacent pieces).

While I do recommend this game, judging by the fact that it isn't anything new and it's fairly short, I'd say wait for a sale or something. At full price I'm not so sure if it's worth it.

reviewText:
Welcome to Day Four of our Headup Games Gameathon. Today I have the privilege of teaching you how to build a bridge. If things go according to plan by the end of this review I will even have a bridge to sell you! I vividly remember when Bridge Constructor was first released that many gamers dumped it straight into the ‘just another simulator’ basket without ever giving it an opportunity. Then as more and more people actually played the game they realized that it was in actuality a pretty solid physics based puzzle game rather than being the pure ‘just another simulator’ game that had first been feared. Unfortunately, it never received the type of critical attention that the game warranted and so it languished sales wise until it was bundled multiple times.

It’s a game that is what the title says it is. You construct and design bridges in the hopes that when you test them that they can bear the weight of cars and trucks crossing them. But be careful in your design because if the structural design is poor then they can even collapse before cars or trucks ever reach the first part of the bridge. This is where it works rather well when looked upon as a puzzle game instead of just as a simulator. When looked upon as a puzzle game it works really well a majority of the time.  The bridges that you are required to build are solved logically. I have a friend who designs blueprints for bridges for a living. I asked him to have a play of the game. He couldn’t get enough of it. However, he did make a strong criticism of the game from a purely architectural perspective. He claimed that some of the puzzles, which he agreed is what this game truly is, have some solutions that the game expects you to use to complete the level at the most successful level (there are multiple solutions to (almost?) every level) that would be structurally unsound while some of the true solutions result in the bridge collapsing.

However, the game doesn’t expect you to be an architectural designer of bridges and it’s just as much fun, if not more so, if you’re not. Probably the most enjoyable achievement that I’ve gotten in the game was the ‘stubborn’ achievement. In order to get the achievement you need to fail spectacularly 25 consecutive times on the one bridge. I’m not so certain if this makes me stubborn or stupid but I’ll take it knowing full well that I sent innocent little cyber minions to their grisly deaths.

For those of you who think presentation is everything the graphics, sound, etc. work perfectly well. This isn’t a title where any of that is significant. However, I do love the sound of the bridge breaking apart. I found it quite amusing. In all, however, the presentation is more than suitable for a game of this type and that’s all that really matters. It wont blow your socks off but it just doesn’t need to.

Bridge Constructor is an enormously fun game that can be quite challenging at times. But as I discovered with the stubborn achievement there’s success to be had in the most miserable of failures. Now, about that bridge I have to sell you….

reviewText:
Bridge Constructor is sort of like TIM2 (shout out to my MS-DOS peeps), but with bridges. You have a limited amount of resources to create a sturdy bridge that spans a gap.


The good:

I like the idea behind it. As I said, it reminds me a lot of the old The Incredible Machine games, but with bridges.


The ugly:

The graphics are passible, the music is okay, but a little bland and repetitive.


The bad:

EVERYTHING ELSE.

Oh, ho, no. I'm sorry, I'm doing my best to be polite, but this game is entirely unplayable. The physics are just straight-up broken in a game about physics and engineering. Cars go flying for no reason, trucks are magnitized to debris, and the actual construction logic makes no sense whatsoever. You can brace a bridge as much as you want, but it's going to go everywhere.

This isn't fun. This is the opposite of fun. This isn't even good enough to be an app game.


Last words:

I wanted this game to work. I really did. This could have been a fantastic physics simulator. In fact, my friends specifically told me to not buy it, but I did because I believed in the idea. It's just too broken. Even if there was a patch (for everything), I would still doubt this would be playable. At ten bucks, it's a borderline scam.


Score: 1.5/10 (and I'm being generous)
Cost: $9.99 USD

Bridge Constructor is a nice and simple way to waste some time. The story in the game is very straightforward. There has been a devastating earthquake that has destroyed the bridges on the islands of Camatuga and the player is in charge of their rebuilding. The problem for the player is that the available budget for the bridge constructions is very tight, so it is not possible to make too advanced solutions or to use the more expensive materials as much as would be ideal. After building the bridges, they have to be tested by letting some cars and/or trucks cross and if the bridge collapses a rethink of the design is needed. When all bridges on Camatuga are functioning for trucks, the game opens up for tests using heavy tanker trucks on the newly constructed bridges, with an often sad and explosive result prompting a redesign of the bridges.

Sometimes the statics of the bridge constructions seem a bit off with collapsing at unexpected places, but usually some engineering common sense and experimenting will solve the problems. It would have been nice to be able to play some of the levels with unlimited budget in order to test some truly exotic bridge designs, but the game is good enough as it is.

Warning to potential buyers: This game has some bridges that won't be solveable with the only structures the game shows you, you'll have to make some weird sh** up and I know this because I had to look up the answer after failing some of the bridges over and over. The game does little to show you which structures you should be thinking about (other than triangles), and often you might not really see if something is working that 10% better than your other builds, and that's often a crucial difference. It also doesn't really explain what materials might fare better beyond the absolute basics of (steel is stronger than wood), and it would've been awesome if they did more to show how the rope can help to support tight budget bridges by connecting along the underside of your bridge from end to end. I only know it distributes weight better this way because some walkthroughs used it. Other materials can be a bit fiddly with load distribution depending on how you've arranged them.
I have played through a bunch of this game and BC: Medieval and while I like both just for the physics puzzle challenge, I find the Medieval one's solutions end up making more sense than this one. It still barely guides you but at least those structures kind of make sense.
In this version you can build diagonal roads (which might be the only way to solve some of these bridges, it's certainly the only way I could find for some) and they end up letting you hold them up with ropes from nonsense structures on the sides because the stone pillars are too expensive or not available.
I still recommend it because I've enjoyed it either way, the physics are simple but pretty consistent, and it's a good little brain work out, but if you want a well-paced puzzle game with some actual help on what to do, this game fails a little on that front. I personally looked up a few answers and still enjoyed trying to figure the level out before I gave up.

Its a fun game, if you're into this kind of thing. My only complaint is that it is in some SERIOUS need of some new game modes or DLC. Namely, in the form of a campaign mode that allows you to earn money based on how much traffic your bridges receive. With the toll money you make, you could build new bridges capable of handling more traffic and larger vehicles, allowing you to earn more money. This game, however, has none of that. Sometimes, you are constrained by a budget that only allows you to build the most laughable of temporary throw-away bridges that crumble on the first use. It also limits your options for construction materials seemingly arbitrarily. It really limits the fun factor. I'm all for a challenge, but when you want me to build a bridge tp cross a 300 foot gap with no support columns in between made of wood that can support a multi-ton fuel tanker-all on a budget of 30,000 dollars-that's where i draw the line.
